BC-CANDLE-CONTROVERSY-1200(2TAKES)-TEX 
CANDLES SOOTHE OUR SENSES BUT COULD THEY ALSO BE HARMING OUR
HEALTH?

 
(Accompanied by BC-CANDLE-TIPS) (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) 
By JESSIE MILLIGAN 
c.1999 Fort Worth Star-Telegram 

   Finally, I have acquired enough candles to make a beautiful
candlescape of flickering light and aromatherapy on my dining-room
table. My bad luck holds, though: I have done so just as the
flourishing $2.3 billion a year candle industry is hit by a
controversy over indoor-air pollution.

   A flurry of recent articles says candles are a health hazard.
Among the concerns expressed in news reports: that metal wicks can
release lead into the home; the flames can send out dangerous
amounts of soot; and that melting wax can release toxins. A Plano,
Texas, couple filed suit in September alleging that candles they
purchased at The Gap, and which they burned for several hours a
day, created soot problems in their home.

   The Gap has responded in the same way as U.S. candle makers,
saying that candles are safe unless misused by consumers.

   So what's the answer? Until the industry resolves the conflict,
a safe step for the consumer is to avoid metal wicks and to limit
exposure to candle emissions.

   The controversy erupted this fall after a University of Michigan
study said that in spite of an agreement 26 years ago by U.S.
candle makers to voluntarily banish lead from metal-core wicks,
several U.S. candles with zinc-cored wicks tested positive for lead
emissions.

   ``Lead was detected in small quantities in emissions from
zinc-based wicks, suggesting that the lead may be a common
contaminant in the zinc, wick or wax,'' Jerome Nriagu, a University
of Michigan professor of environmental health, says in a summary of
his study.

   Nriagu's study showed that one-third of the 15 candles he tested
from the United States and overseas released more lead into the air
than is recommended as safe by the U.S. Environmental Protection
Agency. Amounts of lead in the air increased the longer the candles
burned. Lead emissions were the worst from candles made in China
and the United States, Nriagu said.

   The National Candle Association, a trade organization in
Washington, D.C., challenges the study, saying its independent
tests show that zinc wick cores are widely used in U.S. candles and
are safe. Candle sellers complain that the study doesn't say which
brands were tested, nor does it say if the ``small amounts'' of
lead in zinc-cored wicks were enough to actually cause health
problems.

   _

   Experts _ specifically a NASA scientist, a professor of
environmental health, and a major retailer's manager in charge of
meeting government regulations _ agree that candles do have the
potential to create unhealthful air, but each says that danger can
be avoided if some basic safety tips are followed, such as: don't
let the candles smoke; use candles with cotton or paper wicks; and
burn groups of candles in the fireplace.

   It's relatively easy to find candles with cotton or paper wicks.
Eighty percent of U.S.-made wicks are all cotton or paper, says Jeb
Head, president of Atkins & Pearce, Covington, Ky., the nation's
largest wick maker. Metal wicks, which are used to keep the wick
rigid in some candle shapes and types of wax, are most likely to be
found in votives or unusually shaped candles.

   Then there's the issue of smoke. David Urban, chief of
microgravity combustion science at NASA's Glenn Research Center in
Cleveland, says the combustion byproducts of candle flames are
largely controllable. Urban has made a career out of researching
smoke and flame patterns.

   The bottom line: Keep them out of drafts, and trim the wicks.

   ``You need to limit the wick size to limit the amount of fuel
released into the flame,'' Urban said. ``The longer the wick, the
more wax vaporizes into the flame.'' Drafts cause candles to
flicker, and smoke is released when the flame is disturbed, he
said. ``A little flicker is OK, but not the big flickers.''

   Flickers cause smoke, and that leads to problems of soot, the
airborne partially burned particles that can settle as dust or be
inhaled. All flames have soot, or they will not emit much light and
they'll be blue, like the flame of a gas burner, Urban said.

   Years ago, when candles were used for light, our grandmothers or
great-grandmothers knew that smoky candles made a house dirty. Back
then, candle makers developed self-trimming wicks that curl as they
burn and don't release as much smoke. But now, with candle sales
that are growing at a rate the National Candle Association says is
10 to 15 percent a year, we are burning more, and we may have
forgotten what used to be common wisdom, Urban said.

   _

   MORE nn

   If lead and soot aren't enough to worry about, candles contain
various other agents released into the air when burned, such as
fragrances, wax and dyes.

   Consumers are again left in the dark over the issue of these
``fumes,'' without any guidance from studies or government
recommendations on which candles are safest to burn and how many
are safe to burn at once.

   The state of California, under its Proposition 65 Safe Drinking
Water and Toxic Enforcement Act of 1986, has identified at least
seven toxins in candles' waxes, including benzene, a carcinogen.
Under Proposition 65, a California attorney recently filed an
``intention to file suit'' against 33 candle makers.

   The ``intention to file'' notice gives candle makers and sellers
in California 60 days to reformulate their product or put warning
labels on candles, or be sued. That case is not resolved, said Lana
Beckett, a spokeswoman for ``Prop 65 News,'' a publication that
tracks cases filed under the act. California's attorney general or
county district attorneys can join in the suit if they believe it
has merit, but so far they have not, Beckett said.

   The U.S. Consumer Products Safety Commission has stayed away
from the issue. Spokesman Ken Giles said the commission has
recalled certain candle lines if the wick produced too high a flame
or if the container broke. But he said the commission doubts most
people have enough exposure to large quantities of candle emissions
to make an inquiry into fumes worthwhile.

   Thorough documentation on exposure has yet to be done and will
be a complicated prospect at best because candles are made of so
many different substances and burned under so many different
conditions, said John A. Baker, senior manager for government
regulations at Pier 1 headquarters in Fort Worth, Texas.

   Baker said he burns candles at home, where he groups them in his
fireplace, because he is often burning several at a time to see how
they burn. Any candle smoke will go up the chimney.

   NASA scientist Urban burns candles at home, too, choosing the
classic dinner-table candle known as a taper, which he said
releases the least amount of smoke. Even University of Michigan
professor Nriagu, whose study helped fuel this fire, burns candles
at home _ no metal-wicked ones, of course.

   As for me, I'll burn cotton-wicked candles, maybe just a couple
at a time, and keep them away from drafts.
